original_title: CBSL’s new single policy rate decision boosts stocks
original_body_lines: The Central Bank’s new single policy rate that reduced 50 basis points gave some impetus to the stock exchange yesterday. This also indicated some positive sentiment among investors, stock market analysts said.

Amid those developments both indices moved upwards. The All Share Price Index went up by 102.68 points, while the S and P SL20 was up by 39.4 points. The turnover stood at Rs 3.6 billion with eight crossings.

Those crossings were reported in Seylan Bank, which crossed 22.9 million shares to the tune of Rs 1.3 billion and its shares traded at Rs 60, Hemas Holdings 582,000 shares crossed for Rs 47.8 million; its shares traded at Rs 82, Ambeon Capital 3 million shares crossed to the tune of Rs 45 million; its shares sold at Rs 15, HNB 195,000 shares crossed for Rs 44.7 million; its shares traded at Rs 230, DFCC 500,000 shares crossed to the tune of Rs 43.5 million; its shares sold at Rs 87, Richard Pieris 1 million shares crossed to the tune of Rs 25 million; its shares traded at Rs 25, Sampath Bank 225,000 shares crossed to the tune of Rs 21.2 million and its shares sold at Rs 94 and Pan Asian Bank 750,000 shares crossed to the tune of Rs 20.1 million; its shares sold Rs 26.80.

In the retail market, companies that mainly contributed to the turnover were; Sampath Bank Rs 305 million (3.2 million shares traded), Dipped Products Rs 162 million (3.7 million shares traded), HNB Rs 127 million (557,000 shares traded), Hemas Holdings Rs 126 million (145,000 shares traded), Pan Asia Bank RS 125 million (4.6 million shares traded) and Swiss Tech Rs 80.5 million (2.6 million shares traded). During the day 97.7 million share volumes changed hands in 14900 transactions.
It is said that the banking sector was the biggest contributor to the market, especially Sampath Bank and HNB, while the manufacturing sector featured Dipped Products and Hemas.

Yesterday, the rupee was trading more or less flat at Rs 291.15/20 to the US dollar from 291.10/20 to the US dollar on the previous day, dealers said, while bond yields plummeted after the Central Bank’s monetary policy announcement.

A bond maturing on 15.12.2027 was quoted at 10.42/48 percent, down from 10.85/90 percent. A bond maturing on 15.03.2028 was quoted at 10.50/60 percent, down from 11.07/15 percent. A bond maturing on 15.09.2029 was quoted at 10.90/11.00 percent, down from 11.35/50 percent.
